intro: Pedicellaria lateralis, commonly known as the lateral pedicellaria, is a specialized structure found in certain species of sea hares. This small, calcareous appendage is typically located on the mantle or girdle of the animal. It functions primarily as a defensive mechanism, capable of expelling a cloud of ink or mucus to confuse predators. The pedicellaria lateralis is often equipped with small, movable parts that aid in its defensive actions. Its botanical significance lies in its role as an adaptation to marine environments, reflecting the evolutionary strategies of these unique organisms.
